expanded_description: What happens to firms in monopolistic competition over time? In the short run, they can earn profits or incur losses. But free entry and exit ensure that these outcomes don't last. The long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition has some surprising features: firms earn zero economic profit, but they don't produce at minimum average cost. Instead, they operate with excess capacity—producing less than the efficient scale. This trade-off between product variety and productive efficiency is a key insight of the model. Understanding long-run equilibrium helps explain why we see so many similar businesses and why they don't seem to be operating at peak efficiency.

core_concept.principle: In the long run, monopolistically competitive firms earn zero economic profit, but they do not achieve productive efficiency. (1) Zero profit condition: Free entry and exit drive economic profit to zero, just like perfect competition. However, the mechanism differs: entry reduces demand for each existing firm, shifting their demand curves left until $P = ATC$ at the profit-maximizing quantity. (2) Excess capacity: In long-run equilibrium, firms produce at an output level where $ATC$ is still falling—they are not at the minimum of $ATC$. This means they could lower average cost by producing more, but they don't because demand is insufficient. The difference between the profit-maximizing output and the efficient scale (minimum $ATC$) is excess capacity. (3) Markup: Price exceeds marginal cost ($P > MC$), indicating allocative inefficiency. The markup reflects market power from product differentiation. (4) Product variety trade-off: Society gets product variety (differentiated goods) at the cost of higher average costs and prices than would prevail under perfect competition with homogeneous goods.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a neighborhood with several Italian restaurants. Each has its own atmosphere and specialty dishes. In the long run, they earn just enough to stay in business—no big profits. But none is operating at full efficiency; each has empty tables some nights. They could seat more customers and lower average costs, but they'd have to cut prices or advertising to attract them, which might not be profitable. That's excess capacity—the price of having choices.

sections.introduction: What happens to firms in monopolistic competition over time? In the short run, they can earn profits or incur losses. But free entry and exit ensure that these outcomes don't last. The long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition has some surprising features: firms earn zero economic profit, but they don't produce at minimum average cost. Instead, they operate with excess capacity—producing less than the efficient scale. This trade-off between product variety and productive efficiency is a key insight of the model. Understanding long-run equilibrium helps explain why we see so many similar businesses and why they don't seem to be operating at peak efficiency.

introduction_image.alt: Restaurant street with some empty tables, representing excess capacity
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.2.2: In long-run equilibrium, firms have excess capacity—they could serve more customers at lower average cost.

key_concept.definition: Long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition occurs when entry and exit have eliminated economic profits, leading to zero economic profit for all firms. (1) Adjustment process: If firms earn short-run profits, new firms enter with differentiated products. Entry increases the number of competitors, reducing demand for each existing firm (their demand curves shift left). Entry continues until demand is just tangent to the $ATC$ curve at the profit-maximizing quantity, where $P = ATC$ and profit = 0. If firms incur losses, exit occurs, shifting remaining firms' demand right until losses are eliminated. (2) Long-run equilibrium conditions: (a) $MR = MC$ (profit maximization). (b) $P = ATC$ (zero economic profit). (c) The demand curve is tangent to the $ATC$ curve at the profit-maximizing quantity. (d) $P > MC$ (allocative inefficiency). (e) Firms produce at less than efficient scale (excess capacity). (3) Excess capacity: The difference between the profit-maximizing output and the output that minimizes $ATC$. Because demand is tangent to $ATC$ on the downward-sloping portion (where $ATC$ is still falling), firms could lower average cost by producing more. They don't because they would need to lower price to sell more, and the additional revenue wouldn't cover the cost. (4) Markup: $P > MC$ indicates market power. The size of the markup depends on the elasticity of demand. (5) Welfare implications: Monopolistic competition involves a trade-off. Consumers benefit from product variety (more choices). The cost is productive inefficiency (excess capacity) and allocative inefficiency ($P > MC$). Whether this trade-off is worthwhile is a normative question.
key_concept.context: The long-run equilibrium of monopolistic competition was first analyzed by Edward Chamberlin, who highlighted the excess capacity theorem. This result has important implications: it suggests that monopolistically competitive markets may have "too many" firms, each producing too little output. However, this inefficiency must be weighed against consumer preference for variety. In AP Microeconomics, understanding long-run equilibrium is essential for comparing market structures and analyzing real-world industries like retail and restaurants.

classifications.behavior: In long-run equilibrium, free entry and exit ensure that firms earn zero economic profit. This occurs when the demand curve is just tangent to the average total cost curve at the profit-maximizing quantity. At this point, $P = ATC$, so total revenue equals total cost. If demand were higher, firms would earn profits, attracting entry. If demand were lower, firms would incur losses, causing exit. The tangency condition is the hallmark of long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition. Unlike perfect competition, where the tangency occurs at the minimum of $ATC$, here it occurs on the downward-sloping portion of $ATC$.

image.alt: Demand curve tangent to ATC curve
image.caption: Figure 7.2.4: Zero profit occurs where demand is tangent to ATC.

examples.explanation: In a city with many restaurants, each earns just enough to cover costs in the long run. No restaurant makes economic profits, but each has some loyal customers.

characteristics: Could lower cost by producing more
classifications.behavior: Excess capacity is the difference between the profit-maximizing output and the output that minimizes average total cost (efficient scale). In long-run equilibrium, the demand curve is tangent to $ATC$ on its downward-sloping portion, meaning $ATC$ is still decreasing at the profit-maximizing quantity. If the firm produced more, $ATC$ would fall, but it cannot profitably sell the additional output without lowering price on all units. The result is that firms operate with excess capacity—they could produce more at lower average cost, but choose not to. This is a fundamental inefficiency of monopolistic competition. However, it's the price we pay for product variety. In perfect competition, firms produce at minimum $ATC$ (no excess capacity) but products are homogeneous.

image.alt: Graph showing Q* and QminATC with excess capacity marked
image.caption: Figure 7.2.5: Excess capacity is the gap between Q* and efficient scale.

examples.explanation: Hotels typically operate below full occupancy. They could fill more rooms by lowering prices, but that would reduce profit on existing bookings. The empty rooms represent excess capacity.
Restaurants often have empty tables at off-peak times. They could lower prices to fill them, but that might not be profitable overall.

classifications.behavior: In long-run equilibrium, monopolistically competitive firms charge a price above marginal cost ($P > MC$). This is allocative inefficiency—the value consumers place on additional units exceeds the cost of producing them, but those units are not produced. The markup ($P - MC$) reflects the market power that comes from product differentiation. The size of the markup depends on the elasticity of demand: more differentiation leads to less elastic demand and larger markup. This creates a deadweight loss similar to monopoly, though typically smaller because demand is more elastic. Unlike monopoly, however, the markup doesn't lead to long-run profits because entry eliminates profits—the markup just covers fixed costs.

image.alt: Graph showing P > MC at Q*
image.caption: Figure 7.2.6: Price exceeds marginal cost, indicating allocative inefficiency.

examples.explanation: A coffee shop's marginal cost for an additional cup might be $\$1$, but the price is $\$4$. The $\$3$ markup reflects product differentiation (atmosphere, location, brand).

characteristics: Excess capacity is cost of variety
classifications.behavior: Monopolistic competition involves a fundamental trade-off. On one hand, consumers benefit from product variety—they can choose among different styles, qualities, locations, and brands that better match their preferences. This variety has value. On the other hand, the market structure leads to excess capacity and allocative inefficiency. There is no clear answer to whether the benefits outweigh the costs—it's a normative question that depends on how much consumers value variety. In equilibrium, the market provides the amount of variety that makes zero profits possible. Whether this is socially optimal is debatable. Some economists argue that monopolistic competition may have too many firms (each with too little output) because entrants don't consider the business they steal from existing firms. Others argue that consumer preference for variety justifies the inefficiency.

image.alt: Balance scale with variety on one side and efficiency on the other
image.caption: Figure 7.2.7: Society trades off variety for efficiency.

examples.explanation: Consumers enjoy many craft beer options (variety), but each brewery operates below efficient scale. Society must decide if the variety is worth the higher costs.

principles.principle: Long-Run Equilibrium Occurs Where Demand Is Tangent to ATC
principles.statement: The key geometric condition for long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition is that each firm's demand curve is tangent to its average total cost curve at the profit-maximizing quantity. This tangency ensures two conditions simultaneously: (a) profit maximization ($MR = MC$) and (b) zero economic profit ($P = ATC$). Because the demand curve is downward-sloping, the tangency occurs on the downward-sloping portion of $ATC$, not at its minimum. This is different from perfect competition, where the firm's horizontal demand curve is tangent at the minimum of $ATC$. The tangency condition is the result of entry and exit adjusting until profits are zero.
principles.application: To determine if a monopolistically competitive market is in long-run equilibrium, check whether demand is tangent to $ATC$ at the profit-maximizing quantity. If demand lies above $ATC$, profits exist and entry will occur. If demand lies below $ATC$, losses exist and exit will occur.
principles.example: A restaurant's demand curve just touches its $ATC$ curve at its current output. This indicates zero profit and no incentive for entry or exit.

image.alt: Demand tangent to ATC at Q*
image.caption: Figure 7.2.8: Long-run equilibrium requires demand tangent to ATC.

principles.principle: Monopolistic Competition Results in Excess Capacity
principles.statement: The excess capacity theorem is a key result of monopolistic competition: in long-run equilibrium, firms produce at an output level below the efficient scale (minimum $ATC$). This means they could lower average cost by producing more, but they don't because they would need to lower price to sell the additional output. The amount of excess capacity is the difference between the profit-maximizing output and the output that minimizes $ATC$. This result has important implications: (a) Markets with monopolistic competition may have "too many" firms, each producing too little. (b) There is productive inefficiency—goods are not produced at lowest possible cost. (c) The inefficiency is the cost of product variety. Whether this is socially desirable depends on how much consumers value variety.
principles.application: To measure excess capacity, find the profit-maximizing output $Q^*$ and the efficient scale $Q_{minATC}$. Excess capacity = $Q_{minATC} - Q^*$. This gap indicates the degree of productive inefficiency.
principles.example: A hair salon's efficient scale is 50 customers per day, but it only serves 30. The 20-customer gap is excess capacity. It could serve more at lower cost, but not profitably.

image.caption: Figure 7.2.9: Excess capacity is the gap between actual output and efficient scale.

principles.principle: There Is No Single "Optimal" Amount of Product Variety
principles.statement: The welfare analysis of monopolistic competition is ambiguous. Unlike perfect competition (which achieves efficiency) or monopoly (which creates deadweight loss), monopolistic competition involves a trade-off that is difficult to evaluate. On one hand, consumers value variety—having choices among differentiated products increases consumer surplus. On the other hand, the market structure leads to excess capacity and prices above marginal cost. There is no clear benchmark for what the "right" amount of variety should be. Some economists argue that monopolistic competition may lead to too much variety because entrants don't consider the business they steal from existing firms (business-stealing externality). Others argue that the market provides the variety consumers want. This ambiguity means that policy recommendations for monopolistically competitive markets are less clear-cut than for monopoly.
principles.application: When evaluating monopolistic competition, recognize that efficiency analysis is complex. Don't simply label it as "inefficient" without considering the value of variety. The appropriate policy may be to let the market operate rather than intervene.
principles.example: Should a city limit the number of restaurants to reduce excess capacity? Probably not—consumers value the variety, and the market outcome reflects their preferences.

image.caption: Figure 7.2.10: The welfare effects of monopolistic competition are ambiguous.

worked_examples.title: Finding Long-Run Equilibrium

image.caption: Figure 7.2.11: Find long-run equilibrium price, quantity, and excess capacity.

worked_examples.problem:
A monopolistically competitive firm has the following cost structure: $ATC = 100/Q + 10 + Q$ (so $TC = 100 + 10Q + Q^2$, $MC = 10 + 2Q$). In long-run equilibrium, the firm's demand curve is $P = a - Q$. (The demand curve is linear with slope -1.)
a) In long-run equilibrium, what two conditions must hold?
b) Use these conditions to find the long-run equilibrium quantity and price.
c) Find the value of $a$ (the demand intercept).
d) What is the efficient scale (output that minimizes $ATC$)?
e) How much excess capacity exists?

step_by_step.explanation: (1) Profit maximization: $MR = MC$. $MR = a - 2Q$ (since $P = a - Q$). So $a - 2Q = 10 + 2Q$. (2) Zero profit: $P = ATC$. So $a - Q = 100/Q + 10 + Q$.

step_by_step.step: Solve for Q using both conditions

step_by_step.explanation: Excess capacity = efficient scale - actual output = $10 - 7.07 = 2.93$ units.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) $MR = MC$ and $P = ATC$. b) $Q ≈ 7.07$, $P ≈ 31.21$. c) $a ≈ 38.28$. d) Efficient scale = 10. e) Excess capacity ≈ 2.93 units.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Long-run equilibrium satisfies both profit maximization and zero profit, leading to excess capacity.

worked_examples.title: Graphical Analysis of Long-Run Equilibrium

image.alt: Graph with demand, MR, ATC, MC
image.caption: Figure 7.2.12: Identify key features on the graph.

worked_examples.problem:
The graph shows a monopolistically competitive firm in long-run equilibrium.
a) Label the profit-maximizing quantity $Q^*$ and price $P^*$.
b) Label the efficient scale $Q_e$.
c) Shade the area representing excess capacity.
d) Is the firm earning economic profit? How can you tell?
e) Compare $P^*$ and $MC$ at $Q^*$. What does this indicate?

step_by_step.explanation: $Q^*$ is where $MR = MC$. Go up to demand to find $P^*$. Mark these on the graph.
$Q_e$ is where $ATC$ is minimized (where $MC$ intersects $ATC$). Mark this on quantity axis.
Excess capacity is the horizontal distance between $Q^*$ and $Q_e$. Shade this gap on the quantity axis.
In long-run equilibrium, $P = ATC$ at $Q^*$, so economic profit is zero. The firm earns normal profit only.
$P^* > MC$ at $Q^*$, indicating allocative inefficiency. The markup reflects market power from product differentiation.

worked_examples.final_answer: Graph should show Q* at MR=MC, P* from demand, Qe at min ATC, excess capacity gap, and P > MC.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Long-run equilibrium features zero profit, excess capacity, and $P > MC$.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Long-Run Equilibrium Across Structures
worked_examples.problem:
Compare the long-run equilibrium outcomes for perfect competition, monopolistic competition, and monopoly on the following dimensions:
a) Price relative to marginal cost
b) Price relative to minimum ATC
c) Output level
d) Economic profit
e) Efficiency

step_by_step.explanation: Perfect competition: $P = MC$. Monopolistic competition: $P > MC$. Monopoly: $P > MC$.
Perfect competition: $P = min ATC$. Monopolistic competition: $P > min ATC$ (since producing at less than efficient scale). Monopoly: $P$ may be above, at, or below min ATC depending on demand.

Perfect competition: produces at efficient scale. Monopolistic competition: produces below efficient scale (excess capacity). Monopoly: produces below competitive level, may be above or below efficient scale.
Perfect competition: zero. Monopolistic competition: zero. Monopoly: can be positive (barriers prevent entry).
Perfect competition: allocative and productive efficiency. Monopolistic competition: neither allocative nor productive efficiency, but provides variety. Monopoly: neither, and no variety benefit.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Monopolistic competition shares zero long-run profit with perfect competition but shares $P > MC$ with monopoly, and adds excess capacity.

process_flow.description: Determine if firms are earning profits or incurring losses.
process_flow.mechanism: Compare $P$ to $ATC$ at current output. $P > ATC$ = profit; $P < ATC$ = loss.

image.caption: Figure 7.2.14: Step 1 - Determine short-run profit or loss.

process_flow.description: Based on profit/loss, predict entry (profit) or exit (loss).
process_flow.mechanism: Profit → entry of new firms with differentiated products. Loss → exit of some firms.

image.caption: Figure 7.2.15: Step 2 - Predict entry or exit.

process_flow.description: Entry reduces demand for each firm (shifts left); exit increases demand (shifts right).
process_flow.mechanism: More firms → more substitutes → each firm's demand shifts left. Fewer firms → demand shifts right.

image.caption: Figure 7.2.16: Step 3 - Demand shifts with entry/exit.

process_flow.description: Adjustment continues until demand is tangent to $ATC$.
process_flow.mechanism: Entry/exit stops when $P = ATC$ at profit-maximizing $Q$ (where $MR = MC$).

image.caption: Figure 7.2.17: Step 4 - Equilibrium where demand tangent to ATC.

process_flow.description: Measure gap between actual output and efficient scale.
process_flow.mechanism: Efficient scale at min $ATC$. Excess capacity = $Q_{minATC} - Q^*$.

summary: In the long run, monopolistically competitive firms earn zero economic profit due to free entry and exit. Long-run equilibrium occurs where each firm's demand curve is tangent to its average total cost curve at the profit-maximizing quantity. At this point, two conditions hold: $MR = MC$ (profit maximization) and $P = ATC$ (zero profit). Because demand is downward-sloping, the tangency occurs on the downward-sloping portion of $ATC$, meaning firms produce at less than efficient scale. This results in excess capacity—the gap between actual output and the output that minimizes $ATC$. Firms could lower average cost by producing more, but doing so would require lowering price and would not be profitable. Additionally, $P > MC$ at the equilibrium, indicating allocative inefficiency. Compared to perfect competition, monopolistic competition involves a trade-off: consumers benefit from product variety but pay the cost of excess capacity and higher prices. Compared to monopoly, it shares the $P > MC$ feature but lacks long-run profits. Understanding long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition is essential for analyzing real-world markets where product differentiation is important and for evaluating the trade-off between variety and efficiency.
